results.content: it is very difficult to follow. Too fast, too confusing. The first part was a general overview of the app but it was not explained this way. As we go deeper into learning about the different components, again I have to pause the video all the time as I am trying to apply the demo. A written recap with what  we are seeing or learning would have been welcomed.

response.content:
Hi Anne,
I am sorry because the course did not meet your expectation. ADF is too big framework and I want to give as much as I can of the information because it is hard to cover all topics in detail in one course.
So, I had had two options, first: Go through as much as I can quickly in some topics so that you get an idea about it and in that case you should not do what I am doing but just get an idea.
In the course once I explain something which has too many things I said I will go quickly so that you will get an Idea about it.
second: I will not talk about most of things and give only some information in details. I preferred the first option to give as much as I can of information.
I am sorry again and let me know if you need any help in ADF or if you have any question do not hesitate to contact me.
Thanks,
Sameh
response.content_html:
Hi Anne,
I am sorry because the course did not meet your expectation. ADF is too big framework and I want to give as much as I can of the information because it is hard to cover all topics in detail in one course.
So, I had had two options, first: Go through as much as I can quickly in some topics so that you get an idea about it and in that case you should not do what I am doing but just get an idea.
In the course once I explain something which has too many things I said I will go quickly so that you will get an Idea about it.
second: I will not talk about most of things and give only some information in details. I preferred the first option to give as much as I can of information.
I am sorry again and let me know if you need any help in ADF or if you have any question do not hesitate to contact me.
Thanks,
Sameh

results.content:
The author provides an easy-to-follow, step-by-step approach to learning ADF. This course —as well as the author’s other course— is outstanding. 

I am grateful to the author for his excellent work. It’s well worth the price. I particularly appreciate the pacing of the videos, which are typically ~10 or so minute chunks. This gives students time to break (or restart) without losing their way.
results.content_html:
The author provides an easy-to-follow, step-by-step approach to learning ADF. This course —as well as the author’s other course— is outstanding.

I am grateful to the author for his excellent work. It’s well worth the price. I particularly appreciate the pacing of the videos, which are typically ~10 or so minute chunks. This gives students time to break (or restart) without losing their way.

results.content: Oracle has own legacy technology which is ADF, i as middle java developer (i am oracle certified java programmer) took this course, because many of my clients did demand it from me and i was kind of not fully motivated to do the gig, i have experience with java enterprise in the past (most Spring and JEE Rest, Hibernate endpoint programming), after doing this course i have very good understanding how to develop in ADF, still you will spent a lot of time designing your page, this not a 100% programming course , which is ok. Understanding of JEE is not required , but it will help you to get around of idea how applications work internally. The presentation of this course is hands on , very few slides, personally i have wished more especially about binding stuff and how exactly it works with JSF ADF lifecycles. Still the code works and deployment was successful. For people who just learning java, well i am not sure that it will help you, in my opinion you should have some experience in JEE or Spring to get into this course. For certification its definitely a MUST, you will get your hands dirty , but you will be able in very short time to get "on the bus". My final thoughts , gosh Oracle did awesome product, but still its not perfect and the tool jdevelop has some bugs and strange behavior, but i recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn the ADF!
results.content_html: Oracle has own legacy technology which is ADF, i as middle java developer (i am oracle certified java programmer) took this course, because many of my clients did demand it from me and i was kind of not fully motivated to do the gig, i have experience with java enterprise in the past (most Spring and JEE Rest, Hibernate endpoint programming), after doing this course i have very good understanding how to develop in ADF, still you will spent a lot of time designing your page, this not a 100% programming course , which is ok. Understanding of JEE is not required , but it will help you to get around of idea how applications work internally. The presentation of this course is hands on , very few slides, personally i have wished more especially about binding stuff and how exactly it works with JSF ADF lifecycles. Still the code works and deployment was successful. For people who just learning java, well i am not sure that it will help you, in my opinion you should have some experience in JEE or Spring to get into this course. For certification its definitely a MUST, you will get your hands dirty , but you will be able in very short time to get "on the bus". My final thoughts , gosh Oracle did awesome product, but still its not perfect and the tool jdevelop has some bugs and strange behavior, but i recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn the ADF!

results.content: instructor is very inactive as he does not care about your query or messages and replies to the queries after couple of days or a week. Also, course is not very much informative as he explained very few things.

response.content:
Hi,
This course is for beginners, not Advanced course. The question which I can answer is the question which is related to the course Scope. So if this course is for beginners and you ask me questions related to the JSTL library which is out of the scope, I should not answer this question or at least I can mark it as a lower priority. I am really wondering how this course is not very much informative, this course is 14.5 hours and target beginners and by end of this course the beginner developer will be able to develop a complete ADF application, which means I covered all ADF lifecycles. If you looking for more Advanced topics you can check the Advanced ADF Course which is 18.5 hours. No course will cover everything, the courses open the door for you and help you to go inside a new world and then you should go ahead searching and trying.
Thanks.
response.content_html:
Hi,

So if this course is for beginners and you ask me questions related to the JSTL library which is out of the scope, I should not answer this question or at least I can mark it as a lower priority. I am really wondering how this course is not very much informative, this course is 14.5 hours and target beginners and by end of this course the beginner developer will be able to develop a complete ADF application, which means I covered all ADF lifecycles. If you looking for more Advanced topics you can check the Advanced ADF Course which is 18.5 hours. No course will cover everything, the courses open the door for you and help you to go inside a new world and then you should go ahead searching and trying.
Thanks.
